lines.text: [Thornhill is wearing sunglasses to hide his identity]
Something wrong with your eyes?
Yes, they're sensitive to questions.

[Hanging by their fingers from Mount Rushmore]
What happened with your first two marriages?
My wives divorced me.
Why?
They said I led too dull a life.
You gentlemen aren't REALLY trying to kill my son, are you?

Now you listen to me, I'm an advertising man, not a red herring. I've got a job, a secretary, a mother, two ex-wives and several bartenders that depend upon me, and I don't intend to disappoint them all by getting myself "slightly" killed.
In the world of advertising, there's no such thing as a lie. There's only expedient exaggeration.
I'm a big girl.
Yeah, and in all the right places, too.
That's funny, that plane's dustin' crops where there ain't no crops.

Mr. Kaplan, you are quite the performer. First you're the outraged Madison Avenue advertising executive who claims that he has been mistaken for someone else. Next, you play the fugitive from justice supposedly trying to clear himself of a crime he knows he didn't commit. And now, you're the jealous lover spurned by love and betrayal.
Apparently the only performance that will satisfy you is when I play dead.
Your very next role, and you'll be quite convincing, I assure you.
That wasn't very sporting, using real bullets.
Roger... Pay the two dollars.
No. No, Mother, I have not been drinking. No. No. These two men, they poured a whole bottle of bourbon into me. No, they didn't give me a chaser.
The moment I meet an attractive woman, I have to start pretending I have no desire to make love to her.
What makes you think you have to conceal it?
She might find the idea objectionable.
Then again, she might not.
What possessed you to come blundering in here like this? Could it be an overpowering interest in art?
Yes, the art of survival.
He followed me here from the hotel.
He was in your room?
Sure. Isn't everybody?
Has anyone ever told you that you overplay your various roles rather severely, Mr. Kaplan?
It's going to be a long night.
True.
And I don't particularly like the book I've started.
Ah.
You know what I mean?
Ah, let me think. Yes, I know exactly what you mean.
Then, then your name isn't Kaplan?
Can't say it is, 'cause it ain't.
Roger O. Thornhill. What does the O stand for?
Nothing.
I didn't realize you were an art collector. I thought you just collected corpses.
[Escaping captivity, Roger Thornhill slips in through the window of a darkened hospital room. Immediately the light is snapped on. A woman patient sits up in the bed, reaching for her glasses]
STOP!

[stops]
Oh. Excuse me.
[resumes moving towards the door]
[She has put on her glasses and gets a good look at him]

[plaintively]
Stop.
[Thornhill pauses, turns briefly to warn her off with a raised finger, then rushes out the door]
I tipped the steward five dollars to seat you here if you should come in.
Is that a proposition?
I never discuss love on an empty stomach.
You've already eaten!
But you haven't.
What's wrong with men like me?
They don't believe in marriage.
I've been married twice.
See what I mean?
I don't like the games you play, Professor.
War is hell, Mr. Thornhill. Even when it's a cold one.

If you fellows can't lick the VanDamm's of this world without asking girls like her to bed down with them and fly away with them and probably never come back, perhaps you ought to start learning how to lose a few cold wars.
I'm afraid we're already doing that.
You must have had some doubts about her yourself. You still do.
Rubbish.
Why else would you have decided not to tell her that our little treasure here has a belly full of microfilm?
You seem to be trying to fill mine with rotten apples.
Sometimes the truth does taste like a mouthful of worms.
The truth? I've heard nothing but innuendos.
Call it my woman's intuition, if you will. But I've never trusted neatness. Neatness is always the result of deliberate planning.
How does a girl like you get to be a girl like you?
Lucky, I guess.
If I thought there was any chance of changing your mind, I'd talk about Miss Kendall, of whom you so obviously disapprove.
Yes, for using sex like some people use a flyswatter.
I don't like the way Teddy Roosevelt is looking at me.

[as the police carry Thornhill out of the Art Auction Room, Roger says to the thug who tried to kill Roger twice before in the picture]
I'm sorry old man. Too bad. Keep trying.
I want you to do a favor for me. A big, big favor.
Name it.

I want you to leave right now, stay far away from me, and don't come near me again. We're not going to get involved. Last night was last night, and it's all there was, and it's all there is. There isn't going to be anything more between us. So please. Goodbye, good luck, no conversation, just leave.
You're not taking her on the plane with you?
Of course I am. Like our friends, I too believe in neatness, Leonard. This matter is best disposed of from a great height, over water.
Now, what can a man do with his clothes off for twenty minutes? Couldn't he have taken an hour?
You could always take a cold shower.
When we get out of this, you can ride the train with me again.
Is that a proposition?
It's a proposal, sweetie!
So horribly sad. How is it I feel like laughing?
How do we know it's not a fake? It looks like a fake.
Well, one thing we know. You're no fake. You are a genuine idiot.
War is hell, Mr. Thornhill, even when it's a cold one.
You're police, aren't you? Or is it FBI?
FBI, CIA, ONI... we're all in the same alphabet soup.
And what the devil is all this about? Why was I brought here?
Games? Must we?

Not that I mind a slight case of abduction now and then, but I have tickets for the theater this evening, to a show I was looking forward to and I get, well, kind of *unreasonable* about things like that.
With such expert playacting, you make this very room a theater.
Seems to me you fellows could stand a little less training from the F.B.I. and a little more from the Actor's Studio.
While I'm calling, you can change your clothes.
Where do you propose I do that? In Marshall Fields' window?
I sort of had the men's room in mind.
Did you, now? You're the smartest girl I ever spent the night with on a train.
Well, didn't you hear what I said? I want to be taken to police headquarters. I'm a dangerous assassin, I'm a mad killer on the loose!
You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
We'll get them. We'll throw the book at them. Assault and kidnapping. Assault with a gun and a bourbon and a sports car. We'll get them.

[... ]
it's something about my face.
It's a nice face.
You think so?
I wouldn't say it if I didn't.
Oh, you're that type.
What type?
Honest.
I don't think I caught your name.
I don't think I pitched it.
When I was a little boy, I wouldn't even let my mother undress me.
Well, you're a big boy now.
How do I know you aren't a murderer?
You don't.
Maybe you're planning to murder me right here, tonight.
Shall I?
Please do.
I may go back to hating you. It was more fun.
Sorry love, I'm sentimental.
You've got taste in clothes, taste in food.

[necks Eve]
Hmm, And taste in women. I like your flavor.
Patience is a virtue.
So is breathing.
Roger, I think we should go.
Don't be nervous.
I'm not nervous, I'll be late for the bridge club.
Tell me, why are you so good to me?
Shall I climb up and tell you why?
Seven parking tickets.
Handle with care, fellas. I'm valuable property.

[to Eve]
Who are you kidding? You have no feelings to hurt.

[Referring to the drinks]
We've gotten a head start here, Mr. Thornhill.
That won't last long.
We ahh... we do nothing.
Where are we goin'?
Airport.
For what?
Orders.
How long have you known your client?
Seven years, Your Honor.
Do you know him to be a reasonable man?
Absolutely.
Ha!
Mother.
And you believe there is some...

[a drunk Thornhill looks over the side of the car and sees the rear wheel is dangling over the side of a cliff]
Whewwwwww!

[singing]
I've grown accustomed to my bourbon.
I'm being followed. Can you do something about that?
Yes I can.
Do it.
Who are you?
Mere errand boys carrying concealed weapons. His is pointed at your heart, so, please, no errors of judgment, I beg of you.
What is this? A joke or something?
Yes, a joke. We'll laugh in the car.
Jack Philips, manager for Kingby Electronics.
No, you're not, you're Roger Thornhill of Madison Avenue, and you're wanted for murder on every front page in America. Don't be modest.
Say, do I look heavyish to you?
I'm beginning to think I'm underpaid.
